Let's think about the impact of conservative policies verses the use of government to regulate business in the public interest and to bolster the economy. The latter ideas were NOT started by FDR. They went back further, to the Progressive Reform movement of 100 years ago and even before that. Progressives and labor activists challenged the conservative doctrine of laissez-faire. They worked for government regulation of business. Their efforts produced laws setting maximum hours of work, minimum wages, health and safety regulations in workplaces, the banning of child labor, the breaking up of monopolies and trusts, the regulation of monopolies and trusts, regulations to protect the safety of food and drugs. Progressives also fought for conservation legislation, for setting aside lands for public use and to protect wildlife. 
 
 After World War I, the federal government returned to a conservative, pro-laissez-faire approach, and Republican Presidents promoted no government regulation of business and the cutting of taxes exclusively on the wealthy. What was the result of this smaller government, pro-laissez-faire approach to governing? The Great Depression. The policies of the conservatives gave us 10 years of Depression and a collapse of the capitalist system.
 
 FDR stepped in and used the federal government effectively to rescue democratic capitalism. Not all New Deal programs were effective, because they were trial-and-error efforts, and most New Deal programs were temporary. But FDR resumed and expanded the approach of the Progressive reformers by using government to intervene in the economy, to regulate business, to protect workers and ordinary people, and to provide a safety net for people who, through no fault of their own, were thrown into poverty and in many cases destitution. 
 
 What were the positive long-term results of the New Deal? We have Social Security, a program that is so popular today with the elderly that conservatives have been unable to strip it away by privatizing it or even privatizing part of it. We have the tradition of government action to stimulate the economy and prevent depressions. Even conservatives today believe in this. We have government regulation of banks and the stock market, and government insurance for bank deposits. We have government price supports for farm products, which, while always controversial, have enabled farmers to survive. And the Wagner Act enabled workers in industries to unionize in the late 30s and early 40s, thus turning what had been poor workers into middle-class consumers who in turn helped the economy by consuming and were able to send their children to college. These highly paid industrial jobs have mostly now disappeared with globalization, and that has undermined the American economy and the well-being of American workers generally. 
 
 Since the New Deal, we have added federal government programs that remain highly popular, such as Medicare and government-funded loans and grants for college students, and Head Start. These programs are popular because they provide real benefits to people and enable people to live well and to get ahead by going to college. Children from poor families are given a chance to learn more at an early age with Head Start. These programs have not made people lazy. They have given people a chance. 
 
 The problem with the conservative vision of small government and no government assistance to people is that it leaves many people out, in a capitalist system that seeks to drive down wages in the quest for profits. That tendency, as we have seen, leads to depressions, because low wages undermine the ability of ordinary people to consume. A degree of government redistribution of wealth helps the economy by promoting consumption. That's why tax breaks given now are NOT aimed only at the wealthy, as they were in the days of Calvin Coolidge and Andrew Mellon. Even conservatives recognize that we need to promote consumption, and to do that, we need to give tax breaks to middle-class and poor people, who do the bulk of the consuming. 
 
 One of our biggest challenges today is providing health care to all Americans. And the only way to do it is to use the government. Even Mitt Romney realized that, as he signed into law a bill in Massachusetts that mandates universal health insurance and uses government to help provide universal health insurance in the state. He later disavowed his own health care achievement in Mass. as he tried to sound more conservative in the Republican Presidential race, but he apparently didn't appeal enough to the conservatives in his party, and he dropped out.
 
 I think we are seeing a push from the grassroots not for less government, but for government to step in and provide all Americans with access to affordable health care. This is the wave of the immediate future, I think.
